title: Wage garnishment ordered but they have the wrong guy.
question: I got an email from HR telling me that they are going to start garnishment of my wages. It is from a collection company for some money owed that I don't know anything about. After looking into it I found out the case was filed in San Diego. I've never even lived in San Diego. I am positive this is a case of mistaken identity and called the attorney trying to garnish my wages, but he refused to do anything about it. What can I do to stop the wage garnishment? I pulled my credit report and it shows up on there too. What can I do to get it off my report?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Wage garnishment,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Fraud,Criminal charges for identity theft,Police interrogation,Employee wages,Employee wages and wage theft
answers:
Debt collectors must cease debt collection activities upon receipt of all of the following from the debtor (Ca Civil § 1788.18):
A copy of a police report filed by the debtor alleging that he or she is a victim of an identity theft crime (including, but not limited to, Ca Penal § 530.3) for the specific debt being collected by the debt collector; and
The debtor's written statement that he or she is a victim of identity theft with respect to the specific debt being collected (Ca Civil § 1788.18(a).
Copies of forms for this procedure can be located at the link, below:

The fact that you've never lived in San Diego does not necessarily mean this is a case of mistaken identity. You'll probably be better off identifying the underlying debt that went unpaid and determining if that were a debt you incurred. Maybe it was a debt incurred over the internet?
you will need to hire a local lawyer to assist you ASAP.

Sorry to learn of your difficulty, but this may be just the beginning of a long journey, that may require a lot of attention.
Your focus should be on setting aside this wage garnishment order from the court that has authorized the judgment. You need to gather information about how and why this began, and your connection.
If you are a victim of identity theft or fraud, that should be determined now, and a police report to that effect will likely be helpful to obtain the attention and cooperation of the creditor. If the creditor's attorney will not do anything about it, you should contact the present and former creditor. It may be more difficult determining facts if the creditor is not the original creditor, since the presence of a collection company using garnishment as a remedy, may indicate it represents a debt buyer, rather than an original creditor.
With the facts determined, you may be able to set aside the judgment, or take other legal action.
The details of how and what is best to do, can be handled by an experienced attorney working for you.
The correction of the credit report could start with your contacting the the credit bureaus, explaining your belief you are a victim of identity theft. However, from the standpoint of the credit bureaus at this point in time, all they have is a verifiable fact that there was a judgment against you. You have to change that fact, if possible.
There is no mention if you have had other situations as this, or the amount of the garnishment.
Often victims of identity theft have other incidents or a history. If necessary as a remedy of last resort, you may include these debts in filing bankruptcy, which bankruptcy can have the effect of discharging the debt, stopping the garnishment, and removing the unpaid balance notation from your credit report. You have little time to waste to reduce or end the effect of this garnishment order.

You need to hire an Attorney to go to court in order to have the Judgement vacated. It must be done in the court that entered the Judgement.
